verbs1.question: Great changes ___ in the country, and a lot of railway stations ___.
verbs1.a: have taken place, have been set up
verbs1.b: have been taken place, have been set up
verbs1.c: were taken place, were set up
verbs1.d: have taken place, have set up
verbs1.explain:
- Present perfect tense 
+ First blank: active voice 
+Second blank: passive voice

verbs1.question: Do you think we should call his old teachers and friends as soon as he ___ in town?
I promise that the matter will ___.
That dinner was the most delicious meal we ___.
verbs1.explain:
- Present perfect tense 
- Ever= at any time

verbs1.question: Peter ___ his leg when he ___ in a basketball game against another school.
verbs1.explain:
-Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past. 
- First blank: Simple past tense
- Second blank: simple past continous tense

verbs1.question: These teenagers ___ our soccer team.
verbs1.explain:
- Simple present tense- active voice 
- Belong to: if something belongs to someone, they own it

verbs1.question: Don't get off the bus until it ___.
verbs1.explain:
- Present perfect tense 
- = When the bus has stopped, you can get off

verbs1.question: I'll begin the dictation when you ___ ready.
verbs1.explain:
- Simple present tense 
- Future tense + when simple present tense

verbs1.question: This is a map of the airport that ___ in my home town.
verbs1.explain:
- Present perfect tense 
- Passive voice: have/has been pp

verbs1.question: We'll go with them as soon as we ___ our task.
verbs1.explain:
- Simple present tense 
- Future tense + as soon as simple present tense

verbs2.question: Wendy ___ one day to decide whether she should reject the offer.
verbs2.explain: - Simple past tense- passive voice: was/were + PP

verbs2.question: Tim ___ while he ___ his motorcycle and hurt himself.
verbs2.explain:
-Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past. 
+First blank: Simple past tense
+Second blank: simple past continuous tense

verbs2.question: Henry was disappointed that most of the guests ___ when he ___ at the party.
verbs2.explain:
- The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past. 
+ Past Perfect, when simple past tense

verbs2.question: The police found that the office ___ and a lot of valuables ___.
verbs2.a: had broken into , had been stolen
verbs2.b: has broken into, has been stolen
verbs2.c: had been broken into, were stolen
verbs2.d: has been broken into, were stolen
verbs2.explain:
- First blank: Past perfect tense (The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past (found). + passive voice 
- Second blank: Simple past tense + passive voice

verbs2.question: The new-comer is supposed to report to the director as soon as he ___.
verbs2.explain:
- Simple present tense 
+ Future tense ("is supposed to report" implies action will happen in future)+ as soon as simple present tense

verbs2.question: Where ___ the gift certificate? I can't see it anywhere. "It ___ right here. But now it's gone."
verbs2.b: did you put, has been put
verbs2.c: were you putting, has been put
verbs2.d: had you put, was being put
verbs2.explain:
+First blank:  Present perfect tense
+Second blank: simple past  tense + passive voice

verbs2.question: Hello! I ___ you ___ in Taipei. How long have you been here?
verbs2.explain: - Verb agreement: past perfect tense- simple past; simple past tense- simple past tense; present tense- present tense/future tense....

verbs2.question: When ___ again? "When she _________, I'll let you know."
verbs2.explain:
- First blank: Simple future tense
- Second blank: Simple present tense
+Future tense + when simple present tense

verbs2.question: No permission has ___ for anyone to enter the area.
verbs2.explain: - Present perfect tense - passive voice: have/has been +pp

verbs2.question: Those salesmen asked me to have a drink with them. I said that it was at least five years since I ___ a good drink.

verbs3.question: Mr. Jefferson's students ___ busily when he went to get his handouts he ___ in the office.
verbs3.explain:
- First blank: past continuous tense (Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past (went to) 
+ Past continuous tense, when simple past 
- Second blank: past perfect tense:The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past. 
+ Past Perfect, when simple past tense

verbs3.question: Sandra ___ into Amanda's room when no one ___.
verbs3.explain:
- First blank: simple past tense 
+ Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action (was looking) in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past (slipped)

verbs3.question: If city noises ___ from increasing, people ___ shout to be heard even at the dinner table in the future.
verbs3.b: are not kept, will have to
verbs3.d: do not keep, will have to
verbs3.explain:
-Zero Conditional: used for habitual actions or accepted facts
It is created by if/when simple present tense, simple present tense/ simple future tense

verbs3.question: We could have walked to the department store; it was so near. "Yes. A motorcycle ___ at all necessary."
Do you know our center at all? "No, this is the first time I ___ here."
verbs3.explain: - This is the first time + perfect (present/past) tense

verbs3.question: When I was at college I ___ four foreign languages, but I ___ all except a few words of each.
verbs3.explain:
- First blank: simple past tense 
- Second blank: Present continuous tense

verbs3.question: Come on in, Kevin. We want to show you something. "Oh, how nice of you guys! I ___ you ___ to bring me a present."
verbs3.explain:
- Simple Past :used to describe past facts or generalizations which are no longer true 
+ Be going to

verbs3.question: Has Jeff moved into his new house? "Not yet. The rooms ___"
verbs3.explain: - Present continuous tense - passive voice: be being pp

verbs3.question: I haven't heard from Morris for a long time. "What do you suppose ___ to him?
verbs3.explain: - Present perfect tense:We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs3.question: On Tuesday morning, Ms. Meng went to the market, ___ some tomatoes and visited her uncle.
verbs3.explain: - Simple past tense: We use the Simple Past to list a series of completed actions in the past.

verbs4.question: Kent set out soon after dark ___ home half an hour later.
verbs4.explain: - Simple past tense: We use the Simple Past to list a series of completed actions in the past.

verbs4.question: I'm sorry to keep you waiting. "Oh, not at all. I  ___ here only a few minutes."
verbs4.explain: - Present perfect tense:We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs4.question: Do you like the toy? "No, it ___ very hard."
verbs4.explain: - Simple present tense: the tense in this sentense must agree with tense in question sentence

verbs4.question: I don't really work here; I ___ until the new secretary arrives.
verbs4.explain: - Present continous tense: Use the Present Continuous with Normal Verbs to express the idea that something is happening now

verbs4.question: One more coin is need before my collection ___.
In some parts of the world, tea ___ with milk and sugar.
verbs4.explain: - Simple present tense+ passive voice: Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens.

verbs4.question: How long ___ each other before they ___ married? "For about five years."
verbs4.a: did George and Elizabeth know, were going to get
verbs4.b: have George and Elizabeth known, get
verbs4.c: had George and Elizabeth known, got
verbs4.d: do George and Elizabeth know, are going to get
verbs4.explain: - Past perfect tense + before simple past tense

verbs4.question: Alan's wallet ___ He has looked for it everywhere but still ___ it.
verbs4.explain:
- First blank: present continuous: implies the idea that this action lead to other action (looked) which is still in progress 
- Second blank: present perfect tense

verbs4.question: Claire's colleagues were all surprised when she made it clear that she ___ the office soon.
verbs4.explain: - Future tense in past: would + infinitive

verbs4.question: Can Tony and I join your club, Dad? "You can when you ___ a bit older."

verbs5.question: ___ my socks? "Yes, I saw them on your bed."
verbs5.explain: - Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs5.question: Can I help you, ma'am? "Yes. I bought this clock here yesterday, but it ___"
verbs5.explain: - Simple present tense: Speakers sometimes use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is happening or is not happening now.

verbs5.question: Helen ___ her keys in the office so she had to wait until her sister ___ home.
verbs5.explain:
- Past perfect tense:  expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past
- Past perfect tense + when/until simple past tense

verbs5.question: Who is Vivian Cooper? " ___? I saw you shaking hands with her in front of the bank."
verbs5.explain:
- Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now
+We CAN use the Present Perfect with unspecific expressions such as: ever, never, once, many times, several times, before, so far, already, yet, etc.

verbs5.question: Alice, why didn't you come yesterday evening?" "I ___, but I had an unexpected visitor.
verbs5.explain: - Simple past tense: when you reply to a question, you can use only the auxiliary (do/did..) and keep the same tense

verbs5.question: Your phone number again? I ___ quite catch it. "It's 25788578."
verbs5.explain: - Simple past tense: Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past

verbs5.question: ___ the mini marathon might be put off. "Yes, it all depends on the weather."
verbs5.explain: - Present perfect tense (to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now)+ Passive voice

verbs5.question: As he _________ the survey, Danny ___ asleep.
verbs5.explain:
- Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past. 
+ First blank: Past continuous 
+ Second blank: simple past

verbs5.question: You don't need to describe that policewoman. I ___ her many times.
verbs5.explain: - Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs5.question: I don't think Jim saw me; he ___ into space.
verbs5.explain: - Tense of verb "stared" agrees with tense of verb "saw"

verbs6.question: The price _________, but I doubt whether it will remain so.
verbs6.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs6.question: Hey, look where you are going! "Oh, I'm terribly sorry. ___"
Ben, you've left the light on. "Oh, so I have. ___ and turn it off."
verbs6.explain: - We use the future simple to decide to do something at the time of speaking

verbs6.question: How are you today, Henry? "Oh, I _________ as bad as I do now for a very long time."
verbs6.explain: - We use the present perfect tense

verbs6.question: The witness said that the UFO ___ north to south when she saw it.
verbs6.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs6.question: I first met Lisa two years ago. She _________ at a bookstore at the time.
verbs6.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs6.question: Is this coat yours? "No, mine ___ there by the door.
Nancy is not waiting for us. But she ___!
verbs6.explain: - We use the past simple tense

verbs6.question: Shirley ___ a book about Russia last year but I don't know whether she has finished it.
Hi, Tracy, you look tired "I am tired. I ___ my house all day."
verbs6.explain: - We use the present perfect continuous tense

verbs7.question: Manager Churchill gave up drinking for a while, but soon ___ to his old ways.
verbs7.explain: - We use the Simple Past to list a series of completed actions in the past: gave up- returned

verbs7.question: You're smoking too much. "Only at home. No one ___ me but you."
verbs7.explain:
- Simple present tense: Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. 
+ Smoking is a habit-> simple present tense

verbs7.question: Selecting a mobile phone or a computer for personal use is no easy task because technology ___ so rapidly.
verbs7.explain: - Use the Present Continuous with normal verbs to express the idea that something is happening now

verbs7.question: Peggy ___ table tennis quite well, but she hasn't had time to play since the Chinese New Year.
verbs7.explain: - Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens

verbs7.question: Visitors ___ not to photograph the animals.
verbs7.explain: - Simple present tense: (Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens) + Passive voice

verbs7.question: Not only I but also my classmates ___ tired of having one examination after another.
verbs7.explain: - If you use either-or/ neither-nor/not only- but also: look at the subject closest to the verb. If the subject closest to the verb is singular, use a singular verb; likewise, if the subject is plural, use a plural verb.

verbs7.question: A library with one hundred thousand books ___ to the country as a gift.
verbs7.explain: - When using as well as, except, in addition to, no less than, and with, the noun before these phrases determines the number

verbs7.question: When, where and how to build the new stadium ___ yet.
verbs7.explain:
- Have no information about the stadium. It is true - present simple 
- Stadium can't build it self - passive tense.

verbs7.question: The number of guests invited ___ thirty, but a number of them ___ absent for different reason.
verbs7.explain: - The expression the number is followed by a singular verb while the expression a number is followed by a plural verb

verbs7.question: All the preparations for the contest ___, and we're ready to start.
verbs7.explain: - The passive voice in present perfect

verbs8.question: What are you doing? "I am waiting ___ my children. They should be back for dinner now."
It's freezing outside. You ___ put on your overcoat.
Our parents ___ us stories when we were young.
verbs8.explain:
- - Be/get used to Verb_ing/something: to have experienced something so that it no longer seems surprising, difficult, strange...
- Used to Verb:
+ Expresses the idea that something was an old habit that stopped in the past.
+ Used to talk about past facts or generalizations which are no longer true

verbs8.question: Could you tell me what this phrase means? "Sorry, I don't know it either. Let's look it ___ the dictionary."
verbs8.explain:
- Look up: if you look up information in a book, on a computer etc, you try to find it there 
- Look for = search 
- Look at/over: to turn your eyes towards something

verbs8.question: The teacher told the class to ___ their books and have a test.
verbs8.explain: - Put away:  to put something in the place where it is usually kept

verbs8.question: One of my classmates _________ the China Youth Corps for several years.
verbs8.explain:
- Subject: one of... is singular 
- Have/has been in = join

verbs8.question: This laced hat ___ me.
verbs8.explain:
- Negative/interrogative form of a normal verb: use auxiliary "do/does (interrogative); don't/doesn't (negative) 
- Use "does" for singular subject

verbs8.question: Frank is the kind of person whom everybody likes to ___.
verbs8.explain: - Make friends with somebody: to become friendly with someone

verbs8.question: We _________ you will write to us soon.
verbs8.explain:
- Want/need sbd to do sth
-Wish, hope is grammarically correct in this sentence but "hope" is better in term of meaning

verbs8.question: As soon as he entered his home, Jason took ___ his coat and sat down.
verbs8.explain: - To take off: remove something, especially a piece of clothing

verbs9.question: ___ your clothes right away. We're going to be late.
verbs9.explain:
- Put on: to put a piece of clothing on your body 
- An imperative sentence typically begins with the base form of a verb

verbs9.question: Go on ___ the other exercises after you have finished this one.
verbs9.explain:
- Go on + Verb_ing: Continue with something you are doing
- Go on + To Verb: To do other thing

verbs9.question: The terrible noise from that room simply ___ me mad.
verbs9.explain: - Drive somebody crazy/nuts/mad/insane (=make someone feel very annoyed)

verbs9.question: Her parents died and ___ her a lot of fortune.
verbs9.explain: - Leave (when sbd die): to arrange for someone to receive your money, property, etc after you die

verbs9.question: ___ this essay and tell me what you think of it.
verbs9.explain: - Look through= go through:  to look for something among a pile of papers, in a drawer, in someone's pockets etc

verbs9.question: I asked the director to ___ me a few hours so that we could go over all the problems.
verbs9.explain: - Spare: to make something such as time, money, or workers available for someone, especially when this is difficult for you to do

verbs9.question: It is well known that Thomas Edison ___ the electric lamp.
verbs9.explain: - Invent: to make, design, or think of a new type of thing

verbs9.question: Cheap gasoline of poor quality ___ a lot of smoke.
verbs9.explain: - Give off: to produce a smell, light, heat, a sound

verbs9.question: Sandy and Vincent ___ friends since they met in Bangkok.
verbs9.explain:
- Be friends (with somebody): to be someone's friend 
- Make friends: to become friendly with people

verbs9.question: The sports meet will be ___ till next Saturday because of the bad weather.
verbs9.explain: - Put off (=delay): to delay doing something or to arrange to do something at a later time or date, especially because there is a problem or you do not want to do it now

verbs10.question: When Kelly arrived, she learned Edward ___ for almost two hours.
verbs10.explain: - Away: used to say that someone leaves a place or person, or stays some distance from a place or person

verbs10.question: Will we go skiing or see a movie at home? "Which ___ do?"
verbs10.explain: - Would rather: used to say that you would prefer to do or have

verbs10.question: That little boy really doesn't want to go to the concert, but he doesn't see how he can ___ it.
If no one ___ the phone at home, ring me at work.
Many readers can't ___ quite well unless they know the exact meaning of each word.
verbs10.explain: - Get through: to do an amount of work

verbs10.question: We ___ each other the best of luck in the examination.
verbs10.explain: - Wish: to say that you hope someone will have good luck, a happy life etc

verbs10.question: ___! There's a car rushing toward here!.
I learned to ___ a car when I was twenty-one.
Will somebody go and get Dr. Jefferson? "She's already been ___"
verbs10.explain: - Send for: to ask or order that something be brought or sent to you, especially by writing a letter or by telephone

verbs10.question: Will you ___ me a favor, please?
verbs10.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs11.question: What did you think of the politician's speech? "He _________ for half an hour and indeed _________ something."
verbs11.explain:
- Speak: is to say words out loud, the act of speech; 
- Say: is to speak to someone

verbs11.question: I can hardly hear the music. Would you please ___?
verbs11.explain: - Turn up: to turn a switch on a machine such as an oven, radio etc so that it produces more heat, sound etc

verbs11.question: I love to go to the beach in summer. It ___ great to lie in the sun or swim in the cool sea.
verbs11.explain: - Feel: experience a particular physical feeling or emotion

verbs11.question: Julia _________ Steven's number in the phone book to make sure that she had got it right.
verbs11.explain: - Pick out: to choose someone or something from a group

verbs11.question: Nobody noticed that there was a thief slipping into the house because the lights happened to ___.
verbs11.explain: - Go out: to stop burning or shining

verbs11.question: The captain ___ an apology to the passengers for the unexpected delay.
verbs11.explain: - Make an apology for sth: feel sorry for what happen

verbs11.question: Rather than _________ on a crowded bus, Jimmy always prefers ___ a motorcycle.
verbs11.explain:
- Rather than + infinitve without to
- Prefer + To Verb

verbs11.question: I don't know the movie theater, but it's ___ to be quite a bad one.
verbs11.explain: - They say/people say/ it is said (that): used to talk about something that people think is true

verbs11.question: All the leading newspapers ___ the trade talks among the APEC member countries.
verbs11.explain: - Report: to tell someone about what has been happening, or what you are doing as part of your job

verbs11.question: You are ___ your time trying to persuade the old man; he'll never join us.
verbs11.explain: - Wash your time/money: to use more money, time, energy etc than is useful or sensible

verbs12.question: Nick is looking for another job because he feels that all that he has done never ___ his boss.
verbs12.explain: - Satisfy: to make someone feel pleased by doing what they want

verbs12.question: We didn't plan our book exhibition like that but it ___ well.
verbs12.explain: - Work out:  if a problem or complicated situation works out, it gradually gets better or gets solved

verbs12.question: The group of tourists ___ the train until it disappeared into the distance.
verbs12.explain: - Watch:   to look at someone or something for a period of time, paying attention to what is happening

verbs12.question: ___ that model and then try to copy what he does.
verbs12.explain: - Watch: to pay attention to a situation that interests or worries you to see how it develops

verbs12.question: Do you think the Lakers will be beaten? "Um
verbs12.explain: - Hope: to want something to happen or be true and to believe that it is possible or likely

verbs12.question: It's a wonderful project. But who's going to ___ it ___? "I think Gloria and Wilson will."
verbs12.explain: - Carry out: to do something that you have said you will do or that someone has asked you to do

verbs12.question: The conference ___ last weekend.
verbs12.explain: - Take place: to happen, especially after being planned or arranged

verbs12.question: The library ___ at 9:00 p.m. on workdays.
verbs12.explain: - Simple present tense (Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens)+ active voice

verbs12.question: While this tough meat is being cooked, more water would ___ it.
verbs12.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs13.question: Our manufacturer's carelessness ___ our difficulties.
verbs13.explain: - Simple past tense (express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + active voice

verbs13.question: The World War II ___ in 1939.
verbs13.explain: - Simple past tense (express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + active voice

verbs13.question: As the time went on, his theory ___ to be wrong.
verbs13.explain: - Simple past tense (The Simple Past can be used with a duration which starts and stops in the past) + active voice

verbs13.question: It is said that the music hall can ___ 1,000 people.
verbs13.explain:
- Active voice 
- Seat: if a place seats a number of people, it has enough seats for that number

verbs13.question: The baby is about ___ and can't ___by himself.
verbs13.explain:
- 5 months od= His year old is 5 month
- We often say "five-month-year old
- Passive voice with "can" : can + be + pp

verbs13.question: These young men ___ our volleyball team.
verbs13.explain:
- Belong to(Verb): if something belongs to someone, they own it 
- Subject is plural

verbs13.question: One of the girls ___ while playing basketball.
verbs13.explain: - Get hurt (hurt is adjective in this case)

verbs13.question: Lincoln ___ by many as a friend of freedom.
verbs13.explain:
- Think of: to remember something 
- Passive voice

verbs13.question: The reporter wanted ___ the head of the group, but it was impossible.
Those short stories ___ again.
verbs13.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs14.question: The child labor was made ___ from morning till night in this country.
verbs14.explain:
- Active voice: make sbd do sth 
- Passive voice: sbd + be made to do sth

verbs14.question: The number of the employees in our industry ___ 1 million.
verbs14.explain:
- Simple present tense + active voice 
- The expression the number is followed by a singular verb while the expression a number is followed by a plural verb.

verbs14.question: The cat ___ much farther before it caught that mouse up.
verbs14.explain:
- Past perfect tense: expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past 
+ Past perfect tense + before simple past tense

verbs14.question: The TV series is worthy ___ again.
verbs14.explain:
- Be worthy of sth/doing sth: to deserve to be thought about or treated in a particular way
- Passive voice

verbs14.question: The surgeon said that the patient had to ___ right now.
verbs14.explain: - Passive voice: have/has to + be + PP

verbs14.question: I ___ in the heavy rain on my way to the shopping mall.
verbs14.explain: - Simple past tense (express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + passive voice

verbs14.question: One's success cannot always ___ in terms of money.
verbs14.explain: - Passive voice with modal verb (can/could/should...): can/could/should...+ be + pp

verbs14.question: The lightening ___ the first fire.
verbs14.explain: - May have pp: if something may happen or may be true, there is a possibility that it will happen or be true but this is not certain

verbs14.question: Why are you staying at work so late? "Well, there is a lot of work that ___ by tonight."
verbs14.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Need + To be Past Participle/ V_ing: if before "need" is not person 
- Need + To Verb: If before "need" is person

verbs14.question: In warm weather food ___ long.
verbs14.explain:
- Cannot: used to say that something is impossible or unlikely 
- Passive voice

verbs15.question: This comic book ___ before long.
verbs15.explain:
- Before long= soon 
- Simple future tense + passive voice

verbs15.question: ___ that the earth was the center of the universe.
verbs15.explain:
- It is believed (that): to think that something is true or possible, although you are not completely sure
- Simple past tense: used to describe past facts or generalizations which are no longer true.

verbs15.question: Did you telephone the governor's assistant? "Yes, he ___ back before tomorrow evening."
verbs15.explain: - Simple Present to talk about scheduled events in the near future. This is most commonly done when talking about public transportation, but it can be used with other scheduled events as well)+ passive voice

verbs15.question: An exhibition of sculptures ___ at the gallery next month.
verbs15.explain:
- Simple present tense (use Simple Present to talk about scheduled events in the near future. This is most commonly done when talking about public transportation, but it can be used with other scheduled events as well)+ passive voice 
- Subject (an exhibition)- singular noun

verbs15.question: ___ that Wendy and Vincent can pass the oral test this time.
verbs15.explain:
- " It" is a dummy subject: we use "it" as a subject when we don't want to show who is the true subject 
- It's said/believed that= people say/believe that

verbs15.question: Nobody ___ to smoke inside the house.
verbs15.explain:
-  Simple present tense (Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens)+ passive voice
- Subject (Nobody)-> singular noun

verbs15.question: It is said that the university ___ 100 years ago.
verbs15.explain:
- Simple past tense (Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + passive voice 
- Set up: to start a company, organization, committee etc [= establish]

verbs15.question: These books ___ for parents.
verbs15.explain:
- Simple present tense: used to talk about sth in general 
- Passive voice

verbs15.question: Kent asked his father for some money, but he ___ a good scolding.
verbs15.explain: - Simple past tense (same tense with verb "ask") + passive voice

verbs15.question: Why does Henry look so unhappy? "He has ___ by his friends."
verbs15.explain:
- Present perfect tense + passive voice
- Laugh at somebody/something: to make unkind or funny remarks about someone, because they have done or said something you think is stupid

verbs16.question: The thieves had to throw away all that ___ them while fleeing.
verbs16.explain: - Simple past tense (same tense with verb "had to") + active voice

verbs16.question: Don't be worried. Two doctors ___.
verbs16.explain: - Present perfect tense:(to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now) + passive voice

verbs16.question: Engines ___ by electricity.
verbs16.explain:
- Simple present tense (use to talk about general fact) 
- Make sbd do sth 
- Passive: be made to verb

verbs16.question: This museum ___ within two years.
verbs16.explain: - Simple future tense (express the idea of a general prediction about the future) + passive voice

verbs16.question: The feather overcoat ___ at a high price last winter.
verbs16.explain: - Simple past tense (Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + passive voice

verbs16.question: How are things getting on? "All that can be done ___ "
verbs16.explain: - Present perfect tense: (We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now) + Passive vocie

verbs16.question: It was the shortest film I had ever seen. It only ___ one hour.
verbs16.explain: - Last: to continue for a particular length of time

verbs16.question: Jack is ___ a yellow jacket today.
verbs16.explain:
- Wear: to have something such as clothes, shoes, or jewellery on your body 
- Present continuous tense (to express the idea that something is happening now, at this very moment. It can also be used to show that something is not happening now) + active voice

verbs16.question: The child is not old enough to ___ itself.
verbs16.explain: - Dress = put on clothes: to put clothes on yourself or someone else

verbs16.question: The city's subway ___ more passengers than the buses.
verbs16.explain: - Carry: if a vehicle someone or something somewhere, it take them there

verbs17.question: Would you please ___ the candies among the your classmates?
verbs17.explain: - Divide: if something divides, or if you divide it, it separates into two or more parts

verbs17.question: Nancy ___ herself to be good at negotiating.
verbs17.explain: - Simple past tense (Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) + passive voice

verbs17.question: The hens ___ tens of thousands of eggs every week.
verbs17.explain: - Simple present tense (Use the Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens)

verbs17.question: I found the sentences in the article ___ smoothly.
verbs17.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs17.question: After trying many times, the salesperson ___ to see the manager
verbs17.explain: - Manage:to succeed in doing something difficult, especially after trying very hard

verbs17.question: When Robin arrived, he learned Juliet ___ for almost one hour.
verbs17.explain: - Be away: used to say that someone leaves a place or person, or stays some distance from a place or person

verbs17.question: When my colleague entered the lobby, she ___ him from his picture.
verbs17.explain: - Recognize: to know who someone is or what something is, because you have seen, heard, experienced, or learned about them in the past

verbs17.question: The thermos can ___ four liters of hot water.
verbs17.explain: - Hold: to have the space to contain a particular amount of something

verbs17.question: My feelings were ___ when she didn't accept my love.
verbs17.explain: - Hurt: to injure yourself or someone else

verbs17.question: Prices ___ slowly in the past two years.
verbs17.explain: - Rise: to increase in number, amount, or value

verbs18.question: When the moon ___, we went to bed.
verbs18.explain:
- Rise: (sun/moon/star) to appear in the sky 
- Simple past tense

verbs18.question: How much do these cards ___?
verbs18.explain: - Cost: to have a particular price

verbs18.question: I ___ one hundred dollars for the used bike.
verbs18.explain: -Pay: to give someone money for something you buy or for a service

verbs18.question: My parents and I are going to ___ my uncle at the station tomorrow.
verbs18.explain: - Meet:to go to a place where someone will be at a particular time, according to an arrangement, so that you can talk or do something together

verbs18.question: Can you _________ me the book which you ___ from the school library?
verbs18.explain:
- Lend:to let someone borrow money or something that belongs to you for a short time
- Borrow:to use something that belongs to someone else and that you must give back to them later

verbs18.question: The official ___ bribes from a citizen, but he refused to ___ it.
verbs18.explain: - Accept/take a bribe: money or a gift that you illegally give someone to persuade them to do something for you

verbs18.question: Bob ___ that he had gained the singer's autograph.
verbs18.explain: - Wish: if you wish to do something or you wish to have it done for you, you want to do it or want to have it done

verbs18.question: An idea suddenly ___ me.
verbs18.explain: - Struck: if something strikes you, you think of it, notice it, or realize that it is important, interesting, true etc

verbs18.question: Working with a computer ___ great care.
The police ___ everywhere for the missing bracelet.
verbs18.explain: - Search: to try to find something or someone by looking carefully

verbs19.question: What the spokesman had said in the news ___not exactly right.
verbs19.explain: - Simple past tense: action "prove" happened after action "say"

verbs19.question: We are sad to hear that our team ___theirs in the match yesterday.
verbs19.explain: - Strike: to deliberately hit someone or something with your hand or a weapon

verbs19.question: Sandra can hardly ___ the difference between these two phrases.
verbs19.explain: - Tell:to know something or be able to recognize something because of certain signs that show this

verbs19.question: When Yvonne phoned Irene, Irene could not hear clearly what she was ___.
verbs19.explain:
-You use say when you are mentioning someone's exact words
-You tell	 a story, a joke, a lie, or the truth
- When one person is saying things, you can use talkor speak, but talk is more usual and speak slightly literary

verbs19.question: I am sorry. I've ___ your DVD at home again. I'll bring it tomorrow.
verbs19.explain: - Leave: to make or allow something or someone to stay in a place when you go away

verbs19.question: That boy studies hard. I ___ him to do well on the exam.
verbs19.explain: - Expect:  to think that something will happen because it seems likely or has been planned

verbs19.question: Joshua ___ studying the Chinese geography ten years ago.
verbs19.explain: - Set about: to start doing or dealing with something, especially something that needs a lot of time and effort

verbs19.question: The teacher told the class to ___ their books.
verbs19.explain: - Put away: to put something in the place where it is usually kept

verbs19.question: Your grandma looks ill. You'd better ___ a doctor.
verbs19.explain:
- Call: to telephone someone
- Call on= visit
- Call for: if a group of people calls for something, they ask publicly for something to be done

verbs19.question: Sean was working at his desk last night when the lamp suddenly went ___.
verbs19.explain: - Go out: to stop burning or shining

verbs20.question: Emily and Tracy ___ catch the first train but couldn't.
verbs20.explain: - Try: to attempt to do or get something

verbs20.question: One mad behavior is not enough to ___ a man is mad.
verbs20.explain: - Prove: to show that something is true by providing facts, information

verbs20.question: When did the speech begin? "When all the attendants ___, the candidate began his speech."
verbs20.explain:
- Seat: to arrange for someone to sit somewhere
- Simple past tense (same tense with verb "began") + passive voice

verbs20.question: People usually ___ late to celebrate the New Year.
verbs20.explain: - Stay up: to not go to bed at the time you would normally go to bed

verbs20.question: The bus stopped and ___ the crowd of passengers.
The fire had been ___ 5 minutes before the firefighters arrived.
verbs20.explain: - Put out: to make a fire etc stop burning

verbs20.question: Where is your passport? "My passport was ___."
verbs20.explain: - Steal: to take something that belongs to someone else

verbs20.question: It will ___ one good to have some outdoor activities.
verbs20.explain: - Do one good: Be of benefit to one

verbs20.question: The whole class ___ a lot of time on this math problem.
verbs20.explain: - Spend: to use time doing a particular thing or pass time in a particular place

verbs20.question: The principal ___ to all of the teachers how to solve this issue.
verbs20.explain: - Explain: to tell someone about something in a way that is clear or easy to understand

verbs21.question: The group of scientists ___ full use of the time they could to do experiments.
verbs21.explain:
- Simple past (express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past) 
- Make use of: to make full advantage of something

verbs21.question: Mother came into the kitchen and asked how I was ___ on with the cooking.
verbs21.explain: - Get on: to deal with a job or situation or to make progress

verbs21.question: ___ your words and phrases carefully while writing a composition.
verbs21.explain: - Pick:to choose someone or something from a group

verbs21.question: Sometimes Maggie ___ Jessica's place on her way to the market.
verbs21.explain: - Drop by: to visit someone you know, usually without arranging a particular time

verbs21.question: The number of workers in the international industry ___ more than one hundred thousands.
verbs21.explain:
- Active voice
- The expression the number is followed by a singular verb while the expression a number is followed by a plural verb

verbs21.question: I ___ play the violin when I was young, but I don't now.
verbs21.explain:
- Be/get used to Verb_ing/something: to have experienced something so that it no longer seems surprising, difficult, strange... 
- Used to Verb: 
+ Expresses the idea that something was an old habit that stopped in the past. 
+ Used to talk about past facts or generalizations which are no longer true

verbs21.question: Please ___ yourselves to the pizza.
verbs21.explain: - Help oneself: to take some of what you want, without asking permission - used especially when offering food to someone

verbs21.question: This developing center ___ an area of 200 acres.
verbs21.explain: - Cover: to spread over an area

verbs21.question: I would rather ___.
verbs21.a: surf the Internet than watching TV
verbs21.b: surfing the Internet than watching TV
verbs21.c: to surf the Internet than to watch TV
verbs21.d: surf the Internet than watch TV
verbs21.explain: - Would rather do sth rather do sth else: used to say that you would prefer to do or have something

verbs21.question: While in her college days she used to ___ curly hair.
verbs21.explain: - Wear: to have your hair or beard in a particular style or shape

verbs22.question: Ice ___ into water when its temperature rises beyond 0
verbs22.explain: - Become: to begin to be something, or to develop in a particular way

verbs22.question: The leader is ___his teammates ready now.
verbs22.explain: - Get ready: used to tell people to start a race

verbs22.question: The boss will ___ someone else to do it instead of you.
verbs22.explain: - Get someone to do sth: This construction usually means "to convince to do something" or "to trick someone into doing something."

verbs22.question: I have ___ you my best friend forever.
verbs22.explain: - Consider: to think of someone or something in a particular way or to have a particular opinion

verbs22.question: Many non-English speaking people could not ___ the word thirty from the word dirty.
verbs22.explain: - Tell: to be able to see how one person or thing is different from another

verbs22.question: The minister has done something wrong; she is ready to ___ an apology.
Our school playground ___ an area of 1,500 square meters.
verbs22.explain: - Cover: to spread over an area

verbs22.question: This house ___ cool in summer and warm in winter.
verbs22.explain: - Simple present tense (express a general fact) + active voice

verbs22.question: The lady with glasses ___ a teacher.
verbs22.explain: - Look/sound/feel/taste/seem like: similar to something else, or happening in the same way

verbs23.question: We don't know what ___ really said. It all ___ strange to us.
verbs23.explain:
- Sometimes the pronoun who, that, or which is the subject of a verb in the middle of the sentence. The pronouns who, that, and which become singular or plural according to the noun directly in front of them 
- It all: subject is "it" which is singular

verbs23.question: Your daughter has three children, hasn't she? "Yes, she ___"
A wooden building can easily ___ fire.
verbs23.explain: - Catch: if something catches fire, it starts to burn accidentally

verbs23.question: Jeff ___ his letter into the postbox.
verbs23.explain: - Drop sth into: to take something to a place and leave it there

verbs23.question: As the theater was still closed, I went window-shopping to ___ time.
verbs23.explain: - Kill time: to spend time doing something which is not important while you are waiting to do something important or waiting for something else to happen

verbs23.question: The writer living opposite door is known ___ the public.
verbs23.explain: - Known to the public: famous to public

verbs23.question: Beatrice ___ Harry for ten years.
verbs23.explain:
- Present perfect tense 
- Be married to someone

verbs23.question: Rose wondered if she looked as funny to Wendy as Wendy ___ to her.
You look happy today, Steven. "I like my new suit and dad _________, too."
verbs23.explain:
- Use an auxiliary verb when you want to avoid repeating some part of your sentence (because it can be deduced from the context) 
- Dad does= dad likes

verbs23.question: Here ___ the bus! Hurry up!
verbs23.explain:
- The words here and there have generally been labeled as adverbs even though they indicate place. In sentences beginning with here or there, the subject follows the verb 
+The bus: singular

verbs24.question: Shortly afterwards, I noticed that their work ___.
verbs24.explain:
- Notice/ see/ watch...+ Verb (without to) :you notice /see or watch the whole action 
- Notice/ see/ watch...+ Verb_ing: you notice /see or watch part of the action

verbs24.question: The surface of the wall ___ smooth enough.
verbs24.explain: - " Feel" is normal verb- nagative =doesn't feel

verbs24.question: I tried to persuade Jennifer not to smoke, but she ___ listen to me.
verbs24.explain: - Would not: used to say that someone refused to do something

verbs24.question: Have you ever ___ in an glider?
verbs24.explain:
-Present perfect tense: Have/has + PP
+ Fly- flew- flown

verbs24.question: One should recognize clearly where one's duty ___.
verbs24.explain:
- Simple past tense 
- Lie - lay- lain

verbs24.question: By the end of next month, Ron _________ English for a year.
verbs24.explain: - Future perfect continuous tense: We use the Future Perfect Continuous to show that something will continue up until a particular event or time in the future (by the end of next month)= will/shall + have been Verb_ing

verbs24.question: Jenny ___ eighteen next year.
verbs24.explain: - Simple future tense: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs24.question: Leonardo ___ in Moscow for nine years by this July.
verbs24.explain: - Future perfect tense: The Future Perfect expresses the idea that something will occur before another action in the future= will/shall + have + pp

verbs24.question: ___ seven years since Vincent left his hometown.
verbs24.explain: - It is seven years since + clause

verbs25.question: That was one of the most beautiful campuses we _________.
verbs25.explain: - Present perfect tense: You can use the Present Perfect to describe your experience

verbs25.question: Do you know what ___ from six to eight this morning?
verbs25.explain: - Simple present tense: Speakers occasionally use Simple Present to talk about scheduled events in the near future.

verbs25.question: While Nilson ___ the bulletin, a door somewhere behind him opened.
verbs25.explain: - Past continuous tense: Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past ( a door....opened).

verbs25.question: By the time the police arrived, the robbers _________, leaving two guns on the ground outside the store.
verbs25.explain: - Past Perfect tense: The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past (the police arrived)

verbs25.question: Francis was caught in a traffic jam and by the time she arrived at the airport her teacher's plane ___.
verbs25.explain: - Past Perfect tense: The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past (by the time she arrived)

verbs25.question: The train _________ at the high speed until it reaches the port at about 5:00 p.m.
verbs25.explain: - Future continuous tense: Use the Future Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the future will be interrupted by a shorter action in the future (until it reaches)

verbs25.question: It _________ in the bus station that Watson met an old friend of his.
verbs25.explain: - Past simple tense with dummy subject "it"

verbs25.question: It was not until 10 o'clock that my grandparents _________ to sleep.
verbs25.explain: - Past simple tense: Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past

verbs25.question: He _________ to meet us in front of the McDonald, but he didn't see us.
verbs25.explain:
Very good! Correct 
- Past simple tense: Use the Simple Past to express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past: did go =went

verbs25.question: Johnny _________ he could pass the examination but he failed.
verbs25.explain: -Past perfect tense:The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past (passed- failed)

verbs26.question: Have you got the ticket for the baseball game yet? "Not yet, and I ___ to get it for the last two days."
verbs26.explain: - Present perfect continous: We use the Present Perfect Continuous to show that something started in the past and has continued up until now (for the last two days)

verbs26.question: It's the second time you _________ late for the class this week.
verbs26.explain: - Present perfect: You can use the Present Perfect to describe your experience (the first time, the second time..).

verbs26.question: Hardly _________ they _________ to work when the machines didn't work.
verbs26.explain: -When telling a story in the past time, if an event quickly follows another, these adverbials and partial inversion is used to express the first event. In the inverted clause usually past perfect is used

verbs26.question: ___ three years since the two sisters began learning French.
verbs26.explain: - Simple present tense with dummy subject "it"

verbs26.question: That old woman ___ the street when she was hit by a drunken driver.
verbs26.explain: - Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted (when she was hit...)

verbs26.question: I am sorry, sir, your digital camera isn't ready yet. It ___.
verbs26.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Present continous: express the idea that something is happening now

verbs26.question: I _________ such an horrible story before.
verbs26.explain: - Present perfect tense: use the Present Perfect to describe your experience

verbs26.question: How _________ on with your new job these days? "Not bad."
verbs26.explain: - Present continous: we use the Present Continuous to say that we are in the process of doing a longer action which is in progress; however, we might not be doing it at this exact second

verbs26.question: More than 50 people ___ in traffic accidents over the past four months.
verbs26.explain:
- Passive voice
- Present perfect: We often use the Present Perfect to talk about change that has happened over a period of time

verbs26.question: Helen has _________ for one week.
verbs26.explain: That's right! You chose the correct response.

verbs27.question: The experts ___ the problem for quite some time, but they ___ any solutions yet.
verbs27.explain:
- Present perect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now. We CAN use the Present Perfect with unspecific expressions such as: ever, never, once, many times, several times, before, so far, already, yet, etc. 
- Present perfect continuous: We use the Present Perfect Continuous to show that something started in the past and has continued up until now (they haven't found yet)

verbs27.question: Be quiet! I'm trying to hear what the man ___.
verbs27.explain: - Present continuous: express the idea that something is happening now

verbs27.question: Timmy ___ the same motion.
verbs27.explain: - Simple future tense: express the idea of a general prediction about the future.

verbs27.question: Are the guests about to have dinner? "Yes, it ___ in the dining room."
verbs27.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Present continuous: express the idea that something is happening now

verbs27.question: Where ___ when Lily was in the hospital?
verbs27.explain: - Simple past tense (same tense with verb "was")

verbs27.question: The suspect will answer for what he ___.
verbs27.explain: - Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs27.question: The washing machine _________ by one of our mechanics right now.
verbs27.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Present continuous: express the idea that something is happening now

verbs27.question: I have to make a phone call. Can you wait a second? It ___ long.
verbs27.explain: - Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs27.question: Is this the last exam we have to take? "No, there ___ another two months later."
verbs27.explain: - Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs27.question: If you _________ quiet, I'll tell you what's going on.
verbs27.explain:
-Zero Conditional: used for habitual actions or accepted facts
It is created by if/when + two clauses with the same tense in each clause.

verbs28.question: Can you know when Rachael ___?
verbs28.explain: - Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs28.question: My younger sister ___ the choir ___ last month.
verbs28.explain: - Simple past tense: express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past (in last month). Sometimes, the speaker may not actually mention the specific time, but they do have one specific time in mind.

verbs28.question: I ___ to work, only to find out that it was a holiday.
verbs28.explain: - Simple past tense (same tense with verb "was")

verbs28.question: Milton was so interested in the novel that he ___ it for a long time without taking a rest.
verbs28.explain: - Simple past tense (same tense with verb "was")

verbs28.question: From the 1910s to the 1950s Hollywood ___ the film center of the world.
verbs28.explain: - The Simple Past can be used with a duration which starts and stops in the past.

verbs28.question: It _________ a long time before I decide to study abroad.
verbs28.explain: - Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs28.question: I must admit that this condition _________ better than it was formerly.
verbs28.explain: - Simple present tense (same tense with verb " admit")

verbs28.question: The teacher told the pupils that the earth ___ round.
verbs28.explain: - Simple present tense: The Simple Present can also indicate the speaker believes that a fact was true before, is true now, and will be true in the future. It is not important if the speaker is correct about the fact. It is also used to make generalizations about people or things.

verbs28.question: As soon as Rose ___ how to use the computer, the boss ___ her a higher position.
verbs28.explain:
- Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now 
- Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs28.question: Mr. Tang visited Taipei 101 before _________ for Hong Kong.
verbs28.explain: - Simple past tense:We use the Simple Past to list a series of completed actions in the past

verbs29.question: The group of students had all thought the train ___ by the time they arrived.
verbs29.explain: - Would have pp: used when talking about something that did not happen, or a situation that cannot exist

verbs29.question: My pen ___ "Neither will mine."
verbs29.explain: - Simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future

verbs29.question: ___ down the TV; our baby is asleep.
verbs29.explain: - An imperative sentence typically begins with the base form of a verb: Do it; Look at me...

verbs29.question: Where ___ my new high heels?
verbs29.explain: - Simple present tense: express sth in general

verbs29.question: Lisa got an A in Chemistry. I ___ that she is very intelligent.
verbs29.explain: - Simple present tense:indicate the speaker believes that a fact was true before, is true now, and will be true in the future. It is not important if the speaker is correct about the fact. It is also used to make generalizations about people or things

verbs29.question: Nelson is so rich that he ___ work.
verbs29.explain: - Simple present tense:indicate the speaker believes that a fact was true before, is true now, and will be true in the future. It is not important if the speaker is correct about the fact. It is also used to make generalizations about people or things

verbs29.question: I won't go home until the job ___.
verbs29.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs29.question: When Ms. Hu arrived, the Pengs _________ supper.
verbs29.explain:
- The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past. 
+ Past Perfect, when simple past tense

verbs29.question: After returning home, Jasmine found she ___ her own umbrella in the classroom.
verbs29.explain: - The Past Perfect expresses the idea that something occurred before another action in the past (found).

verbs29.question: I'm afraid I can't gather all the mangoes within such a short time ___ to help me tomorrow morning.
verbs29.explain:
- Used to say that something will happen or be true if something else does not happen or is not true 
- Simple present tense (same tense with verb "gather")

verbs30.question: Ms. Lin ___ a lot of great deeds for others in her life.
verbs30.explain: - Simple present tense: The Simple Past can also be used to describe a habit which stopped in the past. It can have the same meaning as "used to." To make it clear that we are talking about a habit, we often add expressions such as: always, often, usually, never, when I was a child, when I was younger, etc.

verbs30.question: They believed that by using computers the production of their factory ___.
verbs30.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Future tense in past: would + Verb

verbs30.question: This guy ___ to have another try if he can get another chance.
verbs30.explain:
- Mean to do something: to intend to do something or intend that someone else should do something 
- Zero Conditional: used for habitual actions or accepted facts 
- It is created by if/when + two clauses with the same tense in each clause.

verbs30.question: The writer lived in Texas until she _________ to university.
verbs30.explain: - Simple past tense (used with a duration which starts and stops in the past) + passive voice

verbs30.question: Greg _________ a bad cold for a week and still can't get rid of it.
verbs30.explain: - We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now.

verbs30.question: Once you ___ a promise, you must carry it out.
verbs30.explain: - Present perfect tense: used to express finished action that has an influence on the present

verbs30.question: Perhaps it will be a long time ___ from abroad.
Tommy promised his parents that he ___ early but he _________ yet.
verbs30.explain:
- First blank: Future in the Past is used to express the idea that in the past you thought something would happen in the future
- Second blank: present perfect: use the Present Perfect to say that an action which we expected has not happened

verbs30.question: We ___ for long when a bad message came.
verbs30.explain: - Present perfect continuous: We use the Past Perfect Continuous to show that something started in the past and continued up until another time in the past

verbs30.question: The Norman's family, which ___ rather a smaller one, very fond of their new house.
verbs30.explain: - Subject (the Norman's family) can be plural or singular

verbs31.question: Nothing but necessities ___ in the shop.
verbs31.explain:
- Simple present tense 
- Subject: (necessities) is plural

verbs31.question: What ___ when I phoned you last night? "I _________ my papers and was starting to take a bath."
verbs31.c: are you doing, have just finished
verbs31.d: were you doing, had just finished
verbs31.explain: - Past perfect tense, when/before + simple past

verbs31.question: Those children ___ themselves on the beach when the rain ___ and spoilt their fun.
verbs31.explain:
- Use the Past Continuous to indicate that a longer action in the past was interrupted. The interruption is usually a shorter action in the Simple Past. 
+First blank: simple past continuous tense 
+Second blank:Simple past tense

verbs31.question: I turned around and saw that everyone ___ at a woman who ___ in a strange language.
verbs31.explain:
- First blank 
+ Find/ see/ watch...+ Verb (with to) :you find /see or watch the whole action 
+Find/ see/ watch...+ Verb_ing : you find /see or watch part of the action 
- Second blank: past continuous tense: 
+When you use the Past Continuous with two actions in the same sentence (stare-shout), it expresses the idea that both actions were happening at the same time. The actions are parallel.

verbs31.question: You look very busy. I ___ you _________ hard for your task.
verbs31.explain:
- Fist blank: 
+ Simple present tense: The Simple Present can also indicate the speaker believes that a fact was true before, is true now, and will be true in the future 
- Second blank: - Sometimes, we use the Present Continuous to say that we are in the process of doing a longer action which is in progress; however, we might not be doing it at this exact second

verbs31.question: Once you _________ used to the customs here, you ___ this place.
verbs31.explain:
- Get used to: to have experienced something so that it no longer seems surprising, difficult, strange... 
- Second blank: simple future: express the idea of a general prediction about the future.

verbs31.question: One of Professor Chen's works ___ translated into English in 1980.
verbs31.explain: - Simple past tense : express the idea that an action started and finished at a specific time in the past (1980)

verbs31.question: A large amount of money ___ spent on the decoration.
verbs31.explain: - Present perfect tense: (We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now) + Passive vocie

verbs31.question: A lot of trees ___ on each side of the road.
verbs31.explain:
- Grow: if plants grow, they exist and develop in a natural way 
- Subject (trees) is plural 
- Simple present

verbs31.question: We have sold many mobile phones of this kind and the rest ___ on sale today.
verbs31.explain:
- The rest= mobile phones which is plural 
- Simple present

verbs32.question: Someone _________ calling for you at the door.
verbs32.explain:
- The indefinite pronouns anyone, everyone, someone, no one, nobody are always singular and, therefore, require singular verbs 
- Present continuous tense:express the idea that something is happening now

verbs32.question: No one except the two brothers ___ the secret.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (the two brother) is plural
- Simple present

verbs32.question: Class Six _________ reciting the text now.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (class six) is singular 
- Simple present

verbs32.question: ___ of the money ___ used up.
verbs32.explain:
- One-seconds= 1/2
- Use a singular verb with sums of money or periods of time

verbs32.question: The number of the people who ___ by bus ___ increasing.
verbs32.explain:
- Sometimes the pronoun who, that, or which is the subject of a verb in the middle of the sentence. The pronouns who, that, and which become singular or plural according to the noun directly in front of them 
- The expression the number is followed by a singular verb while the expression a number is followed by a plural verb

verbs32.question: All but one ___ here just now.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (all) is plural 
- Simple past tense

verbs32.question: Many students ___ the same kind of mistake before.
verbs32.explain: - Present perfect tense:We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs32.question: Kelly, perhaps Doris, _________ playing with her pet cat.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (Kelly or Doris) is singular
- Present continuous tense

verbs32.question: Laying eggs ___ the ant queen's full-time job.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (Laying eggs) is singular 
- Simple present

verbs32.question: The art works _________ in 1990.
verbs32.explain:
- Subject (The art works) is singular
- Simple past + passive voice

verbs33.question: The Olympic Games ___ held every four years.
verbs33.explain:
- Olympic Games are always taken in plural as there are several sporting events 
- Simple present (express the idea that an action is repeated or usual.) + passive voice

verbs33.question: All that can be used ___ worn out.
verbs33.explain:
- Subject (all that can be used) is singular 
- Present perfect

verbs33.question: Alice's teacher and friend ___ Mr. Lu.
The police ___ the robbers everywhere when they suddenly appeared in a warehouse.
verbs33.explain:
- Subject (the police) is plural 
- Present continuous tense

verbs33.question: The Gulliver's Travels ___ well known to the English world.
verbs33.explain:
- Subject (The Gulliver's travels) is singular 
- Simple present tense

verbs33.question: Only less than 10 ___ of the population of this country ___ on hunting.
verbs33.explain:
- Number + percent: 10 percent
- With words that indicate portions - percent, fraction, part, majority, some, all, none, remainder, and so forth - look at the noun in your of phrase (object of the preposition) to determine whether to use a singular or plural verb. If the object of the preposition is singular, use a singular verb. If the object of the preposition is plural, use a plural verb.

verbs33.question: This kind of cookie ___ good while cookies of that kind ___ different.
verbs33.explain:
- First blank: subject (this kind of..) is singular 
- Second blank: subject (cookies..) is plural

verbs33.question: Over 90 percent of the population of Mainland China ___ uneducated in 2000.
verbs33.explain: - With words that indicate portions - percent, fraction, part, majority, some, all, none, remainder, and so forth - look at the noun in your of phrase (object of the preposition) to determine whether to use a singular or plural verb. If the object of the preposition is singular, use a singular verb. If the object of the preposition is plural, use a plural verb.

verbs33.question: There ___ a knife and fork on the table.
verbs33.explain:
- The words here and there have generally been labeled as adverbs even though they indicate place. In sentences beginning with here or there, the subject follows the verb. 
- Use a plural verb with two or more subjects when they are connected by and.

verbs33.question: Kent has read a part of the book, the rest of which ___ more difficult.
verbs33.explain:
- Subject (which = the book) is singular 
- Active voice

verbs34.question: Robin's family ___ poetry lovers.
verbs34.explain:
- Collective nouns such as family,team and staff may be either singular or plural depending on their use in the sentence. 
- In this case "family" acts as plural

verbs34.question: A dozen _________ twelve, and two ___ twenty-four.
It was reported that ten ___ including an infant.
verbs34.explain:
- Subject (ten= ten persons) is singular 
- Passive voice

verbs34.question: Deer ___ faster than dogs.
verbs34.explain:
- Deer: plural noun 
- Simple present tense: express general facts

verbs34.question: Steam and ice ___ two of the three forms of water.
verbs34.explain:
- Use a plural verb with two or more subjects when they are connected by and.
- Simple present tense: express general facts

verbs34.question: The whole nation _________ greatly moved by President's words.
verbs34.explain:
- Collective nouns such as family,team and staff may be either singular or plural depending on their use in the sentence. 
- In this case "The whole nation" acts as singular 
- Simple past tense

verbs34.question: The students in our school each ___ an electronic dictionary.
verbs34.explain:
- If the word "each" comes before a compound subject, use the singular. 
 ex: each boy and girl has flowers. 
- If the word "each" comes after a plural subject, use the plural verb 
 ex: boys and girls each have flowers.

verbs34.question: 0nly one answer ___ to the question.
verbs34.explain:
- Passive voice 
- Subject (only one) is singular

verbs34.question: The girl sitting by the door is the only one of the students in our class who ___ from the countryside.
verbs34.explain:
- Sometimes the pronoun who, that, or which is the subject of a verb in the middle of the sentence. The pronouns who, that, and which become singular or plural according to the noun directly in front of them. So, if that noun is singular, use a singular verb. If it is plural, use a plural verb. 
- Who= the girl sitting by the door

verbs34.question: Most of the mistakes ___ because of carelessness.
verbs34.explain:
- With words that indicate portions - percent, fraction, part, majority, some, all, none, remainder, and so forth - look at the noun in your of phrase (object of the preposition) to determine whether to use a singular or plural verb. If the object of the preposition is singular, use a singular verb. If the object of the preposition is plural, use a plural verb.
- Mistakes: plural noun.

verbs35.question: Most of Dan's time ___ writing editorials.
verbs35.explain:
- With words that indicate portions - percent, fraction, part, majority, some, all, none, remainder, and so forth - look at the noun in your of phrase (object of the preposition) to determine whether to use a singular or plural verb. If the object of the preposition is singular, use a singular verb. If the object of the preposition is plural, use a plural verb
- Dan's time: singular noun 
- Simple present tense: express habit or repeated things

verbs35.question: A professor and a writer ___ present at the seminar.
verbs35.explain: - Use a plural verb with two or more subjects when they are connected by and.

verbs35.question: The pair of pants _________ worn out.
verbs35.explain:
- Subject( a pair) is singular 
- Present perfect tense: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs35.question: The majority of the students ___ to the teacher attentively.
verbs35.explain:
- Subject ( the majority of the students) is plural noun 
- Present continuous: express the idea that something is happening now, at this very moment

verbs35.question: The pros and the cons each _________ own ideas.
verbs35.explain:
- If the word "each" comes before a compound subject, use the singular. 
 ex: each boy and girl has flowers. 
- If the word "each" comes after a plural subject, use the plural verb 
 ex: boys and girls each have flowers.

verbs35.question: An wood and plastics works, with some satellite factories,___ to be built here.
verbs35.explain:
- Works - a building or group of buildings in which goods are produced in large quantities or an industrial process happens 
- An - singular

verbs35.question: 500 million dollars ___ a large sum of money.
verbs35.explain: - Use a singular verb with sums of money or periods of time.

verbs35.question: 30 kilometers _________ a long way to travel.
Eight plus thirteen ___ twenty-one.
verbs35.explain: - Subject (eight plus thirteen) acts as singular

verbs35.question: There are two roads and either ___ to the city hall.
verbs35.explain: - Two singular subjects connected by either/or or neither/nor require a singular verb

verbs36.question: This couple, together with their new friends, ___there already.
verbs36.explain: -Phrases such as 'together with', 'as well as', and 'along with': The phrase introduced by 'as well as' or 'along with' will modify the earlier word, but it does not compound the subjects--The subject is 'this couple' which is singular and requires singular verb (has been)

verbs36.question: The rest of the plot ___ very wonderful.
verbs36.explain:
- With words that indicate portions - percent, fraction, part, majority, some, all, none, remainder, and so forth - look at the noun in your of phrase (object of the preposition) to determine whether to use a singular or plural verb. If the object of the preposition is singular, use a singular verb. If the object of the preposition is plural, use a plural verb
- The plot is singular--The rest of the plot is/seemsvery wonderful.

verbs36.question: I know that all the students ___ getting on well with Teddy.
verbs36.explain:
- Subject (all the students) is plural
- Simple present tense (same tense with "know")
(Verb tense consistency on the sentence level:
+Keep tenses consistent within sentences.
+Do not change tenses when there is no time change for the action.
-Verb tense consistency on the paragraph level:
+Generally, establish a primary tense and keep tenses consistent from sentence to sentence.
+Do not shift tenses between sentences unless there is a time change that must be shown).

verbs36.question: When and where this event took place ___ still a mystery.
verbs36.explain: Usually, but not always, two or more than two wh-clauses would have a singular verb: Each of the clauses introduced by wh-clauses can be considered as a single unit of thought, and therefore the verb should be the singular

verbs36.question: Not only the equipment but also the workers ___ not there.
verbs36.explain: - To be + adverb/preposition: used to say where something or someone is -Not only. . .but also, and neither. . .nor: The subject closest to the verb determines whether the verb is singular or plural -- the subject is 'the workers' which is plural and requires plural verb (were)

verbs36.question: Some reporters _________ Henry's address in the suburb.
verbs36.explain:
- Subject (some reporters) is plural, it takes plural verb
-Some verbs are normally used in the simple form because they refer to states, rather than actions or processes:
+Verbs refer to mental state (know, forget, mean, imagine...) are not usually used in continuous form.

verbs36.question: Everyone except the boss _________ excited.
verbs36.explain: - To be + adjective: used to describe someone or something - The pronouns each, everyone, every one, everybody, anyone, anybody, someone, and somebody are singular and require singular verbs

verbs36.question: Nothing _________ on that topic.
verbs36.explain:
- The pronouns each, everyone, every one, everybody, anyone, anybody, someone, and somebody are singular and require singular verbs
- Present perfect tense + Passive voice

verbs36.question: Every tool ___ tried then.
verbs36.explain:
- Subject (every tool) is singular 
- Present perfect: We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs36.question: Each man and each woman in the factory ___ to help in the work.
verbs36.explain:
- Use each: when you are thinking about the people or things in a group separately, one by one
+ 'Each' is followed by a singular verb
- Passive voice: be + participle (is asked)

verbs37.question: The following ___ some new popular love songs.
verbs37.explain:
- Real subject is "some new popular love songs" which is plural 
- Simple present tense: use Simple Present to talk about scheduled events in the near future

verbs37.question: My family as well as I _________ glad to meet you.
verbs37.explain: -When using as well as, except, in addition to, no less than, and with, the noun before these phrases determines the number

verbs37.question: Neither he or I _________ for the decision.
verbs37.explain: - Not only. . .but also, and neither. . .nor:The subject closest to the verb determines whether the verb is singular or plural.

verbs37.question: Necessity ___ mother of invention.
verbs37.explain:
- Necessity: singular noun 
- Simple present tense: express general facts

verbs37.question: Only one of the students in our school ___ awarded a copy of English-Chinese dictionary.
verbs37.explain:
- Subject (only one) is singular noun 
- Present perfect:We use the Present Perfect to say that an action happened at an unspecified time before now

verbs37.question: Mathematics ___ the language of science.
verbs37.explain:
- Subject (mathematics) is singular noun 
- Simple present tense: express general facts

verbs37.question: Taking a walk and going jogging ___ beneficial to your health.
verbs37.explain: - Use a plural verb with two or more subjects when they are connected by and.

verbs37.question: ___ hardworking people.
verbs37.explain:
-The + adjective: used before an adjective to make it into a plural noun when you are referring to all the people that the adjective describes

- The Taiwanese(= Taiwanese people) is plural

verbs37.question: That missing woman is the only target that the police ___.
